Solicitation means each and every transaction, activity or conduct, occurring wholly or in part within the City, engaged in by any person who directly or indirectly: 
(1)  Sells; 
(2)  Offers or attempts to sell; 
(3)  Takes or attempts to take one or more sales and/or purchase orders for the later delivery of goods or services; or 
(4)  In any manner requests, asks, solicits, or demands or attempts to request, ask, solicit, or demand anything of value; at any location other than the permanent business place or residence of said person. 
Solicitor means a person who directly or indirectly engages in any solicitation in the City. 
Solicitor permit means the City document requested by an applicant, reviewed by the Chief of Police, and, if approved, issued by the Clerk, according to the procedures set forth in this article, permitting a non-exempt person to engage in solicitation. 
Valid solicitor permit means an issued solicitor permit which is not expired, revoked or suspended. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.030)  
Sec. 12-424. - Prohibited practices. 
No person engaged in solicitation shall: 
(1)  Call at any dwelling or other place between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. except by appointment. 
(2)  Call at any residential dwelling or other place where a sign is displayed bearing the words "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors" or words of similar meaning or nature. 
(3)  Call at the rear door of any dwelling place at any time. 
(4)  Remain on any portion of any premises after being asked to leave by the owner, occupant or other person having authority over such premises. 
(5)  Fail to obey any lawful order of the Chief of Police or any law enforcement officer. 
(6)  Litter, accumulate, or allow the littering or the accumulation of any litter, refuse, or rubbish, in or around the area in which such solicitor is conducting business. 
(7)  Disturb the peace, make noise, or use any sound-amplifying device to attract people if the noise produced is capable of being plainly heard outside a 50-foot radius of the source. 
(8)  Block vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(9)  Damage property. 
(10)  Directly or indirectly misrepresent or make false, deceptive, misleading, or incomplete statements concerning the quality, quantity or character of any good offered for sale, the purpose of the visit, the solicitor's activity, the solicitor's identity, or the identity or purpose of the organization represented. 
(11)  Violate any other ordinance or law. 
(12)  In the event that the person is acting on behalf of a charitable, benevolent, educational or non-profit organization or corporation, refuse to specifically and accurately disclose, as a percentage of the sale or donation price of the goods or services, the portion of the sale or donation price of the goods or services offered which shall actually be used for the charitable, benevolent, educational or non-profit purpose for which the solicitation is being made. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.040)  
Sec. 12-425. - Required practicesDisclosure. 
Each and every person, whether or not exempt from registration under this article, shall, after the initial greeting and before any other solicitation-oriented statement is made to a prospective customer, donee, or solicitee, expressly disclose such solicitor's name, the name of the affiliated organization or business, if any, and a complete and truthful identification of the goods, services, and purpose for the solicitation. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.050)  
Sec. 12-426. Required practicesRight to cancellation; notice. 
Each and every person, whether or not exempt from registration under this article, shall: 
(1)  In the event that such person/solicitor sells or attempts to sell any goods or services for immediate or future delivery, immediately notify the buyer verbally and in writing that the buyer has and shall have, the right to cancel any part or the entire sale and/or other transaction and recover the entire consideration paid, if any, no later than midnight of the third night after closing the transaction and otherwise in compliance with all federal and state laws, rules, regulations, and directives. 
(2)  In the event that such person/solicitor takes a sales and/or other order for the later delivery of goods or services, at the time the order is taken, provide the buyer with a written statement signed by the solicitor containing the terms of the agreement; the amount paid in advance, whether full, partial or no advance payment is made; the name, address and telephone number of the solicitor; the delivery or performance date; and whether a guarantee or warranty is provided and, if so, the terms thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.060)  
Sec. 12-427. - RegistrationRequired. 
Each and every person, prior to engaging in any solicitation or other activities regulated by this article, shall file for registration with the City Clerk, pay the permit fee, seek to obtain, and, if and when issued, hold a valid solicitor permit. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.070)  
Sec. 12-428. - RegistrationExemptions. 
The following persons shall be exempt from the registration provisions of this article: 
(1)  Any person exclusively delivering newspapers, fuel, dairy products or bakery good to regular customers on established routes. 
(2)  Any person selling goods at wholesale to dealers in such goods. 
(3)  Any person selling agricultural products which such person or member of his or her immediate family has grown. 
(4)  Any person who has an established place of business where the goods being sold are offered for sale on a regular basis, and in which the buyer has initiated contact with and specifically requested a home visit by said person. 
(5)  Any person who has had and any person who represents a person who has had a prior business transaction, such as a prior sale or credit arrangement, with prospective customer. 
(6)  Any person conducting a sale required by law or by order of any court. 
(7)  Any person conducting a bona fide auction sale pursuant to law. 
(8)  Any person conducting or engaging in any activity as a member of any benevolent, charitable, educational or non-profit organization or corporation. Except those persons who are not members of the organization and who have been independently contracted by and receive compensation for their solicitation activities from the herein described organizations. 
(9)  Any person engaging in solicitation upon property zoned commercial, business or industrial buy only if the solicitor has received prior express permission from the owner or legal possessor of such property; and the solicitor fully complies with the applicable City outdoor storage and display of merchandise ordinance. 
(10)  Any and all minors but only if an adult responsible for the activities and representations of such minor applies for registration and, in the manner required by this article, is investigated, approved, is issued and holds a valid license, and each minor shall, at all times while soliciting, carry and show upon demand, a photocopy of the responsible adult's permit. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.080)  
Sec. 12-429. - RegistrationProcedure. 
Each and every person not exempt from registration, in addition to complying with each and every other provision of this article, shall: 
(1)  As required by this article, complete and file with the Clerk the registration form, pay the registration fee, obtain approval from the Chief of Police, and have issued and hold a valid solicitor permit prior to engaging in any solicitation, transaction, conduct or other activity regulated by this article. 
(2)  Neither directly nor indirectly engage in any solicitation, transaction, conduct or activity regulated by this article without holding a valid solicitor permit. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.090)  
Sec. 12-430. - RegistrationForm; contents; fee. 
(a)  The registration form furnished by the Clerk shall require the following information which the applicant shall provide fully, accurately, and in writing: 
(1)  Applicant's name, permanent address, telephone number, and local/temporary address (if any). 
(2)  Applicant's age, height, weight, color of hair and eyes. 
(3)  Name, permanent address, telephone number of the business, partnership, firm, association, or corporation the applicant represents, is employed by, or whose merchandise is being sold. 
(4)  Local/temporary address and telephone number from which the applicant's activities will be conducted. 
(5)  Nature of the business and/or activities to be conducted and a brief description of the goods and/or services offered. 
(6)  Proposed method of delivery of goods, if applicable. 
(7)  Make, model and license number of any vehicle to be used by applicant in the conduct of such applicant's activities. 
(8)  Last three cities, villages, or towns where applicant conducted similar activities. 
(9)  Locations where applicant can be contacted for at least 14 days after leaving the City. 
(10)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime or ordinance violation related to applicant's transient merchant business or solicitation activities within the last five years, the nature of the offense, and the place of conviction. 
(11)  A statement appointing the Clerk such person's agent to accept service or process in any civil action brought against the applicant arising out of any sale, service or activity performed by the applicant in connection with the activities of the applicant governed by this article, in the event the applicant cannot, after reasonable effort, be served personally. 
(12)  Attached to the registration form shall be two recent photographs of the applicant, which pictures shall be not less than two inches by two inches and showing the face and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(b)  At the time of filing the registration form with the Clerk, each applicant shall present to the Clerk for examination: 
(1)  A driver's license or some other adequate proof in identity as may be required by the Clerk. 
(2)  A state certificate of examination and approval from the sealer of weights and measures when the applicant's business requires use of weighing and measuring devices approved by state authorities. 
(3)  A state Health Officer's certificate when the applicant's business involves the handling of food or clothing and is required to be certified under state law, which certificate states that the applicant is apparently free from any contagious or infectious disease and dated not more than 90 days prior to the date the registration form is filed. 
(c)  At the time the registration is filed, the applicant shall pay to the City Clerk a non-refundable fee. The non-refundable fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.100)  
Sec. 12-431. - Issuance of permit; investigation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed registration form and fee, the Clerk shall indicate upon the face of the form whether the fee has been paid and then refer it to the Chief of Police who may make and complete an investigation of the statements made upon the registration form, the applicant, or both. 
(b)  The Chief of Police shall either approve or disapprove the registration application upon the face of the registration form and return it to the Clerk. 
(c)  In the event that the Chief of Police approves such registration application, the Clerk shall issue a solicitor permit to the applicant. 
(d)  In the event that the Chief of Police disapproves such registration, the Clerk shall not issue a solicitor permit to the applicant. 
(e)  The Chief of Police may disapprove any registration in the event he or she finds any one or a combination of the following: 
(1)  The registration form contains any material omission or any inaccurate, false, or misleading statement. 
(2)  The applicant violated any provision of any similar or related state, federal, or local ordinance or law anywhere in the previous five years. 
(3)  That there is reason to believe that the applicant violated any provision of any similar or related state, federal, or local ordinance or law anywhere in the previous five years. 
(4)  The applicant failed and/or fails to comply with any provision of this article. 
(5)  The Chief of Police finds that the applicant's proposed activity and/or issuance to the applicant of a City solicitor permit might not be consistent with, or might be contrary to, or might not be in the best interest of, or otherwise not in the furtherance of, the health, safety or welfare of the community. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.110)  
Sec. 12-432. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any person whose registration application is disapproved by the Chief of Police may appeal such decision to the City Council for consideration at one of its regularly scheduled meetings but only upon filing with the City Clerk a written appeal within five days of receiving notice of denial and permit non-issuance. 
(b)  No fee shall be required for such an appeal. 
(c)  The written appeal shall state, with particularity, both the reasons why the applicant contends that the disapproval is not justified and the reasons why a solicitor permit should be issued to the applicant. 
(d)  Upon hearing and considering the reasons proffered at such public hearing by the applicant in favor of issuance and the Chief of Police's reasons against the issuance of a solicitor permit to the applicant, together with whatever evidence may be offered thereto by any person, the City Council, upon not less than four affirmative votes, may authorize the issuance of a solicitor permit to the applicant for such period of time as the Council deems appropriate under the instant particular facts and circumstances. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.120)  
Sec. 12-433. - Required practices; records; registered solicitors. 
Each and every person required by this article to register shall: 
(1)  At all times, keep proper and adequate records of every contact and transaction occurring within the City. 
(2)  Forthwith present any and all City solicitation and related records and documents for inspection and/or photocopying whenever required or requested by the City Clerk, the Chief of Police, or any person acting on behalf or either. 
(3)  Maintain and preserve such records for not less than seven years from the date of the contract or transaction. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.130)  
Sec. 12-434. - Revocation and suspension; solicitor permit. 
(a)  Any solicitor permit issued under this article may be suspended or revoked at any time by the City Clerk, the Chief of Police, or the City Council upon: 
(1)  Violation of any provision of this article by the solicitor or any of the solicitor's agent, representative, or employee; 
(2)  The City Clerk's, Chief of Police's, or City Council's determination that the applicant's continued solicitation is not consistent with or is in any manner detrimental to or contrary to the health, safety, or welfare of the community; or 
(3)  As otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  A registered solicitor may appeal the City Clerk's or Chief of Police's suspension or revocation of his or her solicitor permit to the City Council in the manner set forth in this article for appeals of permit non-issuance. It shall take four affirmative votes of the City Council to overturn such administrative suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.140)  
Sec. 12-435. - Adoption of federal and state laws; violations. 
(a)  To the degree consistent with law, every federal and state law, rule, regulation, and directive, as from time to time amended, governing solicitors, as that term is understood by this article, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set forth. 
(b)  Each and every act required to be performed or prohibited by such adopted federal or state laws, rules, regulations, and directives is required or prohibited by this article. 
(c)  In the event that this provision is in conflict with any other law, rule, regulation, or directive, this article shall govern to the extent permitted by law. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.150)  
Sec. 12-436. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by forfeiture of not less than $50.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for each offense. Each day's continuance shall constitute a separate violation. In default of payment of the forfeiture, the violator shall be imprisoned for not less than ten days nor more than 90 days in the county jail. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.160)  
Sec. 12-437. - Severance clause. 
The provisions of this article are declared to be severable, and if any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this article shall for any reason be held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining sections, sentences, clauses and phrases of this article which shall remain in effect, it being the City Council's legislative intent that this article shall stand notwithstanding the invalidity of any part. 
(Code 1976, § 5.68.170)  
Secs. 12-43812-457. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - BOWLING CENTERS 
 
Sec. 12-458. - LicenseRequired. 
No person shall erect or keep, or permit to be erected, placed or kept upon his or her premises within the limits of the City, any bowling center used or kept for hire without first having obtained a license therefor as provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.010)  
Sec. 12-459. - LicenseApplication; form; information required; Council action. 
(a)  Every application for the license required by Section 12-458 shall be made in writing upon blanks furnished by the City for such purpose, and every such applicant must state their full name and address. In the event that two or more persons are associated together, the full names of all persons financially interested and their addresses must be given. If the applicant is a club, society or corporation, the application shall contain a complete list of the officers. The applicant on the application shall also provide the following information: 
(1)  The premises where said bowling center is to be maintained; 
(2)  The age, home residence address, and current home and business telephone numbers of the applicant; 
(3)  Whether the applicant has previously been engaged in operating a bowling center and, if so, where, when and for what length of time in each place and related information about its operation and history; 
(4)  The name of the owner of the premises on which such centers are to be located. 
(b)  A separate application for each premises shall be filed with the City Clerk who shall forward said application to the Council for action thereon. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.020)  
Sec. 12-460. - Police investigation; report. 
Before any license pursuant to Section 12-458 is issued, an investigation of the premises and of the character of the applicant shall be made by the Police Department and a written report thereon filed with the City Clerk and made a part of the application. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.030)  
Sec. 12-461. - LicenseApplication and police report; Council action. 
Every application for a license pursuant to Section 12-458, together with the Police Department's report accompanying it, shall be presented to the Council at the next meeting following the filing thereof. No license shall be issued until the Council passes favorably on the application. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.040)  
Sec. 12-462. - LicenseFee; issuance. 
The applicant for a license pursuant to Section 12-458 shall pay the prescribed license fee to the City Treasurer on filing the application. The license shall be issued by the City Clerk after it has been approved by the Council. If the license is not granted, the fee deposited shall not be refunded. The license fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.050)  
Sec. 12-463. - LicenseTransferable when. 
No license issued under this article shall be transferable without the prior consent of the Council. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.060)  
Sec. 12-464. - LicensePosting requirements. 
Every licensee shall keep his or her license posted in a conspicuous place in the room in which license centers are kept. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.070)  
Sec. 12-465. - Gambling prohibited. 
No dice shall be thrown for money, merchandise, or credit nor shall cards, raffles or other games of chance, or gambling or betting in any form be permitted in any room or place where any licensed center is located, nor shall there be any open or secret connection with any other room or place where persons congregate for gambling, or engage in any manner in gambling or immoral purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.080)  
Sec. 12-466. - Sanitary, lighting, and ventilation requirements. 
All rooms or places where licensed centers are maintained shall be kept at all times in a clean, healthful and sanitary condition, and shall be well ventilated and lighted, and shall comply with all lawful rules or orders of the Health Department or other health authorities of the City. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.090)  
Sec. 12-467. - View obstruction not permitted. 
No blinds, screens, curtains, partitions or other obstructions shall be permitted to shield from view any such room or place where licensed centers are maintained, and a clear view of the interior of any such room or place from the front entrance to the rear thereof must be maintained at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.100)  
Sec. 12-468. - License; revocation; hearing. 
Any license issued under this article may be forfeited or revoked by a majority vote of the Council for any disorderly or immoral conduct permitted on the premises covered by the license, or for the violation of any rules, regulations, ordinances or laws governing or applying to any such licensed centers, or the premises where the same are maintained; provided, however, that before any such license is revoked, the licensee by given an opportunity to be heard. In case of the revocation of any such license, no portion of the license fee shall be returned. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.110)  
Sec. 12-469. - Violation; penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article may, upon conviction therefor in court, have his or her license suspended or revoked by the court and/or suspended, revoked or not renewed by the City Council, and shall further be punished by the imposition and payment of a forfeiture in an amount of not less than $50.00 nor more than $1,000.00 together with the costs of prosecution and in default of the payment of such imposed forfeiture, shall be imprisoned until such forfeiture and costs are paid, not to exceed 90 days. Each day's continuance of a violation constitutes a separate offense. This penalty shall be independent and exclusive of the right of the Council to suspend, revoke and/or non-renew any license or permit. 
(Code 1976, § 5.72.120)  
Secs. 12-47012-491. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - SERVICE STATIONS 
 
Sec. 12-492. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to establish minimum standards and requirements governing location, operation, maintenance and regulation of gasoline service stations within the City. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.010)  
Sec. 12-493. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Aesthetic treatment means an area set aside for the planting of grass, shrubs, trees, flowers, or other natural treatment; however, the Plan Commission may count as much as five percent towards the aesthetic treatment requirement if the proposed building has unusual natural aesthetic appeal. 
Bay means an area within the building intended for, or usable as, a location to service, repair or wash a car. Each area large enough to accommodate one car shall be considered as one bay. 
Emergency services means a service rendered to a customer that is unusual due to some type of urgent situation. This service, due to unusual circumstances, requires services performed outside the building, but in no case takes more than 24 hours to complete. 
Gasoline dispensing station means a station dispensing gasoline and related automotive products. 
Gasoline service station means a station dispensing gasoline and related automotive products, and in addition, provides auto servicing and repairs in a service bay. 
JATS Plan means an approved plan of the Janesville Area Transportation Study showing future widening of some arterial streets. 
Lot width means the horizontal distance between the side lot line of a lot, measured at right angles to the lot depth, said measurement to be made at the rear line of the required front yard. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.020; Ord. No. 74-383, § 1, 1974)  
Sec. 12-494. - General provisions. 
(a)  All activities necessary for, or incidental to the operation of the station, shall be conducted entirely within the building with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Emergency services and tire changing; 
(2)  Dispensing of gasoline and minor service functions customarily performed while dispensing gasoline. 
(b)  All materials, goods, merchandise, parts, or supplies, both new and used, except those necessary for the permitted outside uses outlined under Subsection (a) of this section shall be kept, stored or displayed entirely within the building, regardless of whether such materials, goods, merchandise, parts or supplies are intended for sale, use, dispensation or disposal. The following shall be permitted provided they conform to all setback lines: 
(1)  Outside tire cabinets or tire merchandisers for tire display and storage of tires only, will be permitted outside the building, provided that such cabinets are of a totally enclosed type. 
(2)  Coin-operated machines for vending of soft drinks, cigarettes and similar items will be permitted outside the building, provided that such machines are located in an orderly manner. 
(3)  Trash or refuse storage areas will be permitted outside the building provided that such storage areas are completely screened from view from any point on the perimeter of the site by an enclosure of the same material as the immediate adjacent wall of the station building, located immediately adjacent to, and attached to the service station building. Such an enclosure shall extend from ground level to a minimum of five feet. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.030)  
Sec. 12-495. - New station construction; application approval or denial procedure; fee. 
(a)  Any person intending to build a gasoline station shall apply to the City Plan Commission for approval to construct such station. Approval must be obtained prior to making application for a building permit. The applicant shall submit to the secretary of the City Plan Commission an application fee accompanied with plans showing the building elevations, display of merchandise, storage of supplies, storage of refuse, and a plot plan of the site showing lot size, driveways, sign locations, aesthetic treatment and parking. Such fee shall be retained whether or not approval is granted. The license fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. 
(b)  In order to determine if the application is in the public interest, the Plan Commission, after holding a public hearing, may deny permission to construct a new station if any one, or combination of the following conditions is found to exist: 
(1)  The use of the site, in the judgment of the Plan Commission, for a service station would impair, endanger, inhibit, or in some manner impede the proper flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic in, about, or on the street or street upon which such service station fronts. 
(2)  The auxiliary service units, such as bulk tank trucks and other serving units would, in the judgment of the Plan Commission, be inherently dangerous in the geographical location due to population, or traffic density or pattern. 
(3)  The use of the geographical location, in the judgment of the Plan Commission, would be aesthetically unreasonable, and would not be compatible with surrounding structures, green areas, or land uses. 
(4)  The proposed station does not comply with all applicable standards presented in this section, or with other applicable laws or codes. 
(c)  In determining its finding, the Plan Commission shall take into account the character and use of adjoining buildings, and those in the vicinity, the number of persons residing or working in such buildings, and traffic conditions in the vicinity. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.040)  
Sec. 12-496. - Abandoned, vacant or inoperative stations. 
Where the applicant for approval to construct a new station, or the person, firm, or corporation whose products it is intended that the station will dispense, owns, formerly owned within the past 36 months, or controls any abandoned, vacant or inoperative station or stations within the City, the application for the service station shall be accompanied by an additional fee, and a definite and complete plan for the future of the abandoned, vacant, or inoperative station or stations. Such plan shall be approved by the City Plan Commission before, or as part of the approval of application for the new station, and the Commission shall establish a reasonable time limit within which such plan must be carried out. The additional fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. For the purposes of this section, any station which has been abandoned, vacant or inoperative for any seven consecutive days in the 60-day period prior to the application for a new station, or which has been used for other than a gasoline station for any seven consecutive days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, in said 60-day period, shall be considered to be an abandoned, vacant or inoperative station. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.050)  
Sec. 12-497. - Operative stations; regulation compliance. 
(a)  All operative stations, at the time of adoption of the ordinance codified in this article, which have been in continual operation for at least 30 days prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article shall comply with the provisions of Section 12-494 within two years of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article. 
(b)  All stations in existence or under construction, but not in operation at the time of adoption of the ordinance codified in this article, and stations which have not been in continual operation for at least 30 days prior to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this article shall comply with the provisions of Sections 12-494 and 12-496 before resuming or continuing operations. 
(c)  All stations which are in existence at the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article, which do not conform to the provisions of Subsection (a) of this section and Section 12-495(b)(1) through (3) and Sections 12-499, 12-500, 12-502 through 12-504 may continue as a nonconforming use if all other provisions are met as described in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.060)  
Sec. 12-498. - Minimum standards; compliance. 
All stations shall comply with the minimum standards in Sections 12-492 through 12-504, unless specifically excluded elsewhere in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.070)  
Sec. 12-499. - Minimum lot area. 
The minimum lot area shall be 10,000 square feet for each gasoline dispensing station, and 10,000 square feet plus 2,000 square feet per bay for each gasoline dispensing and service station. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.080)  
Sec. 12-500. - Minimum lot width. 
The minimum lot width shall be 100 for each gasoline dispensing station and 120 for each gasoline dispensing and service station. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.090)  
Sec. 12-501. - Parking requirements. 
The parking requirements for gasoline service stations shall be as follows: 
(1)  One stall shall be provided for each employee on duty when fully staffed. 
(2)  In addition, three stalls shall be provided for each bay intended for service, repair or other use. 
(3)  The minimum size of such stall shall be nine feet by 20 feet. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.100)  
Sec. 12-502. - Driveway opening. 
No driveway opening shall be located closer than 40 feet to a block corner, or closer than 15 feet to a property line. No driveway opening shall exceed 35 feet at the curb, and 30 feet at the sidewalk line. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.110)  
Sec. 12-503. - Planted areas. 
(a)  At least ten percent of the gasoline station lot shall be permanently set aside, planted and maintained in grass, flowers, shrubs, trees, or devoted to other aesthetic treatment acceptable to the Plan Commission. 
(b)  The area between the sidewalk and the future curbline as shown in the JATS Plan may be counted as part of the ten percent required, but in no case counted as more than five percent, although it is not part of the area of the lot upon which the ten percent is computed. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.120)  
Sec. 12-504. - Location. 
Stations, except those in the Central Business Zone, or Industrial Zones, shall be located only on property fronting on federal, state or county highways, as such highways are routed and marked within the City. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.130)  
Sec. 12-505. - Appeals. 
Any interested person who feels aggrieved by a decision of the Plan Commission may appeal from such decision to the City Council by serving a notice of appeal in writing upon the City Clerk within 20 days from the date of such decision. Any interested person may appeal from the decision of the City Council to the circuit court for Rock County, Wisconsin, by filing a notice of appeal in writing with the Liquor License Advisory Committee of said court within 30 days from the date of decision of the City Council. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.140)  
Sec. 12-506. - Article provisions to take precedence. 
This article shall take precedence over all other regulations thereto within this Code governing the location, operation, maintenance and regulations of gasoline service stations. 
(Code 1976, § 5.76.150)  
Secs. 12-50712-536. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - TAXICABS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference Authority of city to regulate and license taxicabs and taxicab operators, Wis. Stats. § 349.24. 
 
Sec. 12-537. - Taxicab company licenseRequired. 
No person, firm or corporation shall operate any cab, taxicab or any other vehicle carrying passengers for hire within the City without first securing a taxicab company license from the City. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.010)  
Sec. 12-538. - Taxicab company licenseApplication; information required; fee; bond; issuance when. 
(a)  Applicants for a taxicab company license, pursuant to Section 12-537, shall file with the City Clerk an application giving the name of such applicant, the number of such vehicles to be used or operated and the length of time for which such license is desired and shall pay to the City Treasurer the license fee provided in Section 12-29. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by a good and sufficient indemnity bond issued by some surety or indemnity company duly authorized to transact business in the state, which bond or insurance shall describe each vehicle to be licensed by factory number, maker's name and carrying capacity. Said bond or insurance shall provide that the owner or operator issuing the same shall be directly liable for and shall pay all damages, whether to persons or property, that may be recovered against said owner or operator by reason of the negligent use and operation of each such licensed vehicle for a minimum of $50,000.00 to any one person or $100,000.00 for any one accident. The bond or insurance provided for by this subsection shall be deemed to include any policy of insurance or other contract in writing by which any surety or insurance company authorized to execute such contract shall assume the liability prescribed in this subsection. The City of Janesville shall be named as certificate holder for such a bond or insurance and shall be notified if such bond or insurance lapses within five days of the lapse of such bond or insurance. If any such bond so filed becomes inoperative or lapses for any reason, the vehicle or vehicles covered thereby shall not be operated until a bond meeting the requirements of this subsection has been filed. 
(c)  Upon receipt of any such application, accompanied by the bond or insurance required by Subsection (b) of this section and payment of the prescribed fee for each taxicab, the City Clerk shall issue to the applicant a taxicab company license for each taxicab for which application, bonding/insurance and fee payment have been made. The prescribed fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. The issued license shall bear the signature of the City Clerk. Any denial of a new or renewal application or issuance by the City Clerk for any reason may be appealed within 30 days of the denial by the applicant to the City Council by filing a written appeal, signed by the applicant, setting forth in detail the reasons why the taxicab company license should be issued. Upon such filing, the matter shall be placed upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the City Council. The applicant shall be provided an opportunity to appear and, under oath, present evidence and testimony as to why the license should be issued, and the City Clerk shall be provided an opportunity to show why the license should not be issued. Each party may provide testimony, present witnesses, and cross-examine witnesses. A majority vote of the City Councilmembers present at the hearing shall govern and a tie vote sustains the City Clerk's decision to not issue the license. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.020)  
Sec. 12-539. - Taxicab company licenseInformation required; register kept; exhibited; additional vehicles. 
Each taxicab company license shall be numbered and dated and shall contain the name of the person applying for the same. It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep a register of all licenses granted under this article wherein shall be stated the number of such license, to whom issued and the date thereof. Every person, firm or corporation who may be licensed as aforesaid shall forthwith cause the license number to be plainly exhibited on the right and left side of each vehicle so operated in figures not less than 1½ inches in height. Where any licensee operates more than one such vehicle, all vehicles operated by such licensee shall be individually numbered, consecutively from one to the total number of such vehicles, and on each such vehicle there shall be exhibited on each side thereof, in letters of like size, the individual vehicle number in addition to the license number. Such vehicle number and license number shall be separated by a dash. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.040)  
Sec. 12-540. - Taxicab company licenseRented or leased vehicles. 
This article shall require a taxicab company license for every vehicle which may be leased or rented for use as a taxicab with or without a driver. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.050)  
Sec. 12-541. - Municipal taxicab driver's licenseRequired. 
No person, other than a licensed driver holding a municipal taxicab driver's license issued by the City, shall operate any cab, taxicab or any other vehicle covered by Section 12-537 carrying passengers for hire within the City limits. 
(Code 1976, § 5.90.060)  
Sec. 12-542. - Municipal taxicab driver's licenseApplication; fee; information required; denied when; receipt; Council determination. 
(a)  Applicants for a municipal taxicab driver's license shall file an application with the City Clerk and shall pay a license fee in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. Such application shall state the applicant's name, age, physical description, the person, firm or company for whom the applicant is to drive and any convictions in any court of record for any offense within the previous five years. Two passport-size photos shall be submitted with each application, one of which will be retained by the City Clerk's office and the other will be attached to the license when issued. No such license shall be issued to any person under the age of 18 years, nor shall any license be granted to any applicant who has been convicted of driving while under the influence of intoxicants or other related violations within one year prior to the date of filing such application. Applicants must possess a valid driver's license issued by the state in which they reside, be eligible to drive in Wisconsin, and have no current Wisconsin revocations or suspensions of driving privileges. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application and presentation of a receipt showing the payment of the prescribed fee, only if the applicant satisfies all of the requirements set forth in Subsection (a) of this section and all of the other requirements for taxicab drivers and driver's license applications set forth of this article, and only if issuance is recommended by the Chief of Police, the City Clerk shall issue to the applicant a taxicab driver's license to said applicant. The issued license shall be dated, contain the name of the licensee and be signed by the City Clerk. An application for a new or renewal taxicab driver's license may be denied due to the applicant's regular or CDL driver license or taxicab driver's license related history of drug or alcohol violations and/or recent (within five years) moving traffic violations and/or other related offenses, when, in the discretion of the City Clerk or Chief of Police, it is deemed necessary and/or appropriate to deny said application for the public safety, welfare, peace, good order, and/or health of the community. Any denial of the application or issuance by the City Clerk for any reason may be appealed by the applicant to the City Council within 30 days of the denial by filing a written appeal, signed by the applicant, setting forth in detail the reasons why the taxicab driver license should be issued. Upon such filing, the matter shall be placed upon the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the City Council. The applicant shall be provided an opportunity to appear and under oath present evidence and testimony as to why the license should be issued, and the City Clerk shall be provided an opportunity to show why the license should not be issued. Each party may provide testimony, present witnesses, and cross-examine witnesses. A majority vote of the City Councilmembers present at the hearing shall govern and a tie vote sustains the City Clerk's decision to not issue the license. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.070)  
Sec. 12-543. - Municipal taxicab driver's licenseExemptions. 
The provisions in this article requiring taxicab drivers to be licensed shall not apply to persons operating such vehicles under a permit for special occasions as provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.080)  
Sec. 12-544. - Municipal taxicab driver's licenseNontransferable. 
No municipal taxicab driver's license shall be transferable. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.090)  
Sec. 12-545. - Municipal taxicab driver's licenseDisplay required. 
All persons mandated by this article to have a municipal taxicab driver's license shall have and keep the same displayed in a conspicuous place on the inside of the vehicle within clear view of all passengers. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.100)  
Sec. 12-546. - Fares; display in cab required. 
All persons mandated by this article to have a municipal taxicab driver's license shall at all times conspicuously and legibly post and display their fares, fees and other charges in writing inside the cab within clear view of all passengers. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.102)  
Sec. 12-547. - Special occasion permitRequirements. 
The City Clerk may issue to any person, firm or corporation a permit to operate a cab, taxicab, or other conveyance, carrying passengers for hire, for any special day of occasion subject to the conditions in Sections 12-548 through 12-552. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.110)  
Sec. 12-548. - Special occasion permitApplication fee; Treasurer's receipt; information required; display. 
Applications for special permits must be made to the City Clerk and the same must be accompanied by a payment of a fee in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set forth in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. The applicant must state the number of vehicles to be operated by such driver and the names of persons who are to act as drivers. Such permit shall not be issued for any vehicle unless the City Clerk is satisfied that the driver thereof is a fit person to operate the same. Such special permit shall bear the date for which it is issued, contain the name of the driver and be signed by the City Clerk. A separate permit shall be issued for each vehicle to be used. Such permit shall be displayed within clear view of all passengers. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.120)  
Sec. 12-549. - Special occasion permitBonding procedure. 
Each applicant for any special permit shall file with the City Clerk an indemnity bond to cover each vehicle to be operated under such permit in the same manner and amount as prescribed in Section 12-538. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.130)  
Sec. 12-550. - Special occasion permitOperator to be licensed or listed in permit; effective date. 
No special permit fee shall be required for the operation of any licensed vehicle on any such special occasion, but all drivers of any vehicle, whether licensed or operating under permit for special occasion, must either be licensed or included and listed in the application for said permit and approved by the City Clerk. Each such special permit shall state the day for which it is issued and shall have no force or effect on any other day. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.140)  
Sec. 12-551. - Licenses and permitsRevocation when. 
In addition to the penalties prescribed in Section 12-553, the City Council may at any time revoke any taxicab company or municipal taxicab driver's license, or special permit provided for in this article, when in its discretion public safety requires such revocation. A municipal taxicab driver's license is automatically revoked for the period of one year upon the licensee's conviction of driving a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicants or controlled substances or upon suspension or revocation of the licensee's state operating privileges. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.150)  
Sec. 12-552. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to vehicles which are owned by licensed funeral directors nor to the drivers of such vehicles when employed by such licensed funeral directors in the conduct of funerals, weddings and christenings. Any such vehicles, and the drivers thereof, shall be licensed as required by this article if used in any other class of work. Furthermore, every vehicle and the driver thereof must be licensed, even though the same is employed in the conduct of a funeral, wedding or christening if such vehicle is not owned by a licensed funeral director. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.160)  
Sec. 12-553. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction therefor in court, have his, her, or its license revoked and/or suspended, and shall pay to the City a forfeiture in the amount of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of the payment of such forfeiture and costs, the violator shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, not to exceed 60 days. 
(b)  Each day's continuance of any violation constitutes a separate offense. 
(c)  A violation of any provision of this article by an employee, agent or taxicab driver shall constitute a violation of and by the owner, licensee, and/or taxicab company. 
(d)  In addition to, and not in lieu of, any other forfeitures or penalties set forth in this article, the City may seek and/or the court may impose injunctive relief in favor of the City and against any violation of this article. 
(e)  Penalties shall be independent and in addition to the right of the City Council to revoke or suspend any license or permit granted under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5.80.170)  
Secs. 12-55412-584. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVIII. - WEIGHTS AND MEASUREMENTS PROGRAM[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference Municipality authorized to regulate, administer and charge for the weights and measurements program, Wis. Stats. § 98.04. 
 
Sec. 12-585. - Adoption of State Weights and Measurements Program. 
The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 98.04, inclusive of the Wisconsin Statutes and any applicable Wisconsin Administrative Codes, each as from time to time amended and renumbered, describing and defining regulations and procedures with respect to weights and measurements, are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this article as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute or code so incorporated by reference is required or prohibited by this article. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of such statutes and administrative codes incorporated by this article are also adopted and incorporated herein. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.010)  
Sec. 12-586. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial weighing device or measuring device means those devices used or employed in establishing the size, quantity, extent, area or measurement of quantities, things, produce or articles for sale, hire or award, or in computing any basic charge or payment for goods or services rendered on the basis of weight or measure. 
Occasional sale means an isolated and sporadic sale which takes place where the infrequency, in relation to the other circumstances, support the inference that the seller is not pursuing a vocation, occupation or business or a partial vocation or occupation or part-time business as a vendor of items subject to weights and measures as covered by this article. Such occasional sale shall be for special events or temporary events operating infrequently and not at a regular and/or permanent location for conducting transactions requiring the use of weighing or measuring devices. 
Testing entity means the City of Janesville or any other person, business organization, or any other entity, including the State of Wisconsin, under contract with the City of Janesville, that provides testing and related services for the City of Janesville weights and measures program. 
Weights and measures program means and includes the administration and enforcement of this article and Wis. Stats. § 98.04 and any related sections and Wisconsin Administrative Code section, as from time to time amended and renumbered. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.020)  
Sec. 12-587. - Participation required. 
(a)  Except as provided in Subsections (b) and (c) of this section, each and every person, corporation, limited liability corporation, limited liability partnership, business, group, organization or other entity who holds, owns, possesses, operates and/or maintains weights and measures, weighing or measuring devices and/or systems and accessories relating thereto which are used commercially within the City of Janesville in determining the weight, measure, count or cost of commodities or things sold or offered or exposed for sale on the basis of weight, measure or count is deemed to be a participant in the City of Janesville weights and measures program subject to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Occasional sales are exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Devices tested under the jurisdiction of another municipality or a non-City of Janesville related testing program by the State of Wisconsin and used temporarily in the City of Janesville for no more than five consecutive days per year are exempt under this section from the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.030)  
Sec. 12-588. - Assessments/costs/fees. 
(a)  The City of Janesville Clerk-Treasurer and/or his or her designee shall annually assess costs and fees to each participant holding, owning, possessing, operating, and/or maintaining such devices and utilizing the services provided in this article based on the number of weighing and measuring devices held as of the date of the last inspection and testing of such devices. Such assessments shall be determined no later than 90 days from the receipt of any billing received by the City of Janesville from the State of Wisconsin or other testing entity relating to weights and measurement testing and calibration. The total of the costs and fees assessed and collected shall not exceed the actual costs of the weights and measures program billed to the City together with a 15 percent City administration cost which shall be added thereto. Such total assessment shall then be divided and assessed proportionally against each and every person, corporation, limited liability corporation, limited liability partnership, business, group, organization or other entity tested which gave rise to the City's expense. 
(b)  The City of Janesville Clerk-Treasurer and/or his or her designee shall prepare a statement of assessments and mail to each participant said statement together with an invoice for the amount of the participant's assessment. Invoices shall be mailed by First Class Mail no later than 30 days after the assessments have been determined as set forth in Subsection (a) of this section. This will be the per-device fee. The charge to each participant shall be based on the total number of devices it holds, owns, possesses, operates or maintains, multiplied by the proportionately distributed individual assessment amount. 
(c)  Each and every participant who is subject to inspection and testing and/or holds, owns, possesses, operates or maintains, devices subject to inspection and testing is subject to this article, liable for said assessment and the payment of such assessments, and shall pay to the City of Janesville the fee assessed no later than 30 days from the date the invoice is mailed. 
(d)  Schedules, statements, notices and invoices shall be considered mailed to a participant when mailed by First Class Mail to the location where the device was held, owned, possessed, operated, maintained and/or tested. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.040)  
Sec. 12-589. - Non-payment; noncompliance; enforcement. 
In the event that the assessed fee is not paid in full by the assessed participant within 30 days of the mailing of the invoice, the Clerk-Treasurer may charge and levy the amount of such unpaid assessment or part thereof or allocate such unpaid assessment against the participant's tax bill if not paid before the next immediately following October 1. Any assessment fee or part thereof not paid within 30 days of invoicing, shall accrue interest at the rate of one percent per month upon the outstanding delinquency until paid in full. In addition, failure to pay within the 30 days of the mailing of the invoice constitutes a violation of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.050)  
Sec. 12-590. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall forfeit and pay to the City, as and for a penalty, a forfeiture in the following dollar amounts, together with the costs of prosecution for each offense, and in default of the payment of such penalty shall be imprisoned for not more than 60 days for each unpaid forfeiture in addition to such other penalties, remedies, sanctions and relief as may be, from time to time, provided by law: 
(1)  For a first offense, a forfeiture of not less than $30.00 but not more than $500.00. 
(2)  For a second offense, a forfeiture of not less than $50.00 but not more than $500.00. 
(3)  For a third offense, a forfeiture of not less than $75.00 but not more than $500.00. 
(4)  For a fourth offense, a forfeiture of not less than $100.00 but not more than $500.00. 
(5)  In addition to the imposition of forfeiture, the City may request and the court may grant injunctive relief, abatement, mandamus and such other equitable relief and orders as the court may deem appropriate to terminate the violations. 
(b)  Each occurrence shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Each day's continuance of a violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1976, § 5.86.060)  
Secs. 12-59112-613. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIX. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference Food safety regulations, generally, Wis. Stats. § 97.01 et seq. 
 
Secs. 12-614. - Sanitation regulations; conformance. 
Every person operating any hotel, tavern, restaurant, lunchroom, lunch stand or counter, cafeteria, candy store, fountain or other place dispensing drinks, grocery store, meat market, butcher shop, or other place of any kind or nature selling food or drink for human consumption shall keep the same in a clean and sanitary condition and shall comply with all rules, regulations and orders of the proper health authorities of the state and Rock County. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.010)  
Sec. 12-615. - License; suspension; when. 
In case any violation of Section 12-614 should occur in any premises for which a food license has been issued, which in the judgment of the Rock County Health Officer or Rock County Sanitarian is potentially dangerous to the health of the customers or employees of the establishment, either of such officers is empowered to suspend the food license until the violation is corrected to the satisfaction of the officer. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.020)  
Sec. 12-616. - Effect of article on other business regulations. 
This article does not affect or limit the provisions of Section 12-29. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.040)  
Sec. 12-617. - Fly control. 
All places which handle food and drink for human consumption shall be securely protected by having screens at all doors and windows or shall provide other acceptable means to effectively keep flies and other insects from gaining access to the interior of the building and food-stuffs. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.050)  
Sec. 12-618. - New eating establishments. 
New eating establishments shall provide: 
(1)  Hand-washing facilities with both hot and cold running water; 
(2)  Filtered hood over cooking area; 
(3)  Three-compartment sink in lieu of dishwasher or in case of replacement; 
(4)  Sneeze shield on self-service area or other acceptable protection; 
(5)  Two restrooms, one for each sex, in all drive-ins; 
(6)  Steam tables maintaining a minimum temperature of 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.070)  
Sec. 12-619. - Dispensing food or drink out-of-doors; parking area requirements. 
No person shall operate a place of business dispensing food or drink in the out-of-doors unless the drive-in and parking areas are so surfaced or treated as to eliminate dust and dirt from either wind or traffic. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.080)  
Sec. 12-620. - State regulations adopted. 
Chapter ATCP 75 (Retail Food Establishments) of the Wisconsin Administrative Code (Wis. Admin. Code ch. ATCP 75) is adopted by reference. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.090)  
Sec. 12-621. - Temporary restaurant permits. 
Temporary restaurant permits may be granted by the City Council pursuant to Section 12-620 and shall not be required to conform to the requirements of Sections 12-617 through 12-618. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.100)  
Sec. 12-622. - Violation; penalty. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall pay to the City a forfeiture of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00, together with the costs of prosecution, for each offense, and in default of the payment of such penalty shall be imprisoned in the county jail not less than five days nor more than 60 days. 
(Code 1976, § 8.48.110)  
Secs. 12-62312-652. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XX. - CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE 
 
Sec. 12-653. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Cable Television Franchise Ordinance." 
(Code 1976, § 15.56.010)  
Sec. 12-654. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross revenues of a grantee means and includes: 
(1)  Any and all direct and indirect revenues of any grantee, including, but not limited to, any and all annual gross revenues, income, commissions, remunerations, compensation, capital gains, other gains, receipts, benefits, payments, earnings, recompense, restitution, settlements, gifts and/or reparation of whatsoever kind or nature howsoever derived and/or received directly or indirectly by any grantee, in connection with, and applicable to, the operation of the Janesville Cable Television System, including, but not limited to, basic service tier, extended basic, monthly subscriber service fees, pay cable fees, installation fees, reconnection fees, late charges, commissions derived from home shopping, advertising, advertising commissions, rental of converters, rental of remotes, any and all other rental income, and any and all other sources of income of whatsoever kind or nature. 
(2)  The term "gross revenues" does not include any taxes or services furnished by any grantee and imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the City, state or other governmental unit and collected by any grantee on behalf of said governmental unit. 
Gross receipts means all revenues received by and paid to a video service provider by subscribers residing within the City for video service, or received from advertisers, including all of the following: 
(1)  Recurring charges for video service. 
(2)  Event-based charges for video service, including pay-per-view and video-on-demand charges. 
(3)  Rental of set top boxes and other video service equipment. 
(4)  Service charges related to the provision of video service, including activation, installation, repair, and maintenance charges. 
(5)  Administrative charges related to the provision of video service, including service order and service termination charges. 
(6)  Revenues received from the provision of home shopping or similar programming. 
(7)  All revenue, except for refunds, rebates, and discounts, derived by the video service provider for advertising over its video service network to subscribers within the City. If such revenue is derived under a regional or national compensation contract or arrangement between the video service provider and one or more advertisers or advertising representatives, the amount of revenue derived for the City shall be determined by multiplying the total revenue derived under the contract or arrangement by the percentage resulting from dividing the number of subscribers in the City by the total number of regional or national subscribers that potentially receive the advertising under the contract or arrangement. 
Notwithstanding Subsections (1)(7) of this definition, the term "gross receipts" does not include any of the following: 
(1)  Discounts, refunds, and other price adjustments that reduce the amount of compensation received by a video service provider. 
(2)  Uncollectible fees, except that any uncollectible fees that are written off as bad debt but subsequently collected shall be included as gross receipts in the period collected, less the expenses of collection. 
(3)  Late payment charges. 
(4)  Amounts billed to video service subscribers to recover taxes, fees, surcharges or assessments of general applicability or otherwise collected by a video service provider from video service subscribers for pass through to any federal, state, or local government agency, including video service provider fees and regulatory fees paid to the FCC under 47 USC 159, as from time to time amended or renumbered. 
(5)  Revenue from the sale of capital assets or surplus equipment not used by the purchaser to receive video service from the seller of those assets or surplus equipment. 
(6)  Charges, other than those described in Subsection (1) of this definition, that are aggregated or bundled with amounts described in Subsection (1) of this definition, including, but not limited, to any revenues received by a video service provider or its affiliates for telecommunications services, information services, or the provision of directory or Internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing, if a video service provider can reasonably identify such charges on books and records kept in the regular course of business or by other reasonable means. 
(7)  Reimbursement by programmers of marketing costs actually incurred by a video service provider. 
(Code 1976, § 15.56.030)  
Sec. 12-655. - Incorporation of federal and state laws. 
(a)  Each and every federal and state law pertaining to and/or regulating the cable television industry and local government involvement and empowerment thereto are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set forth. 
(b)  Each and every act and prohibition required therein are required by this article, unless a provision in this article and/or in any franchise agreement between the City and a grantee provides otherwise, in which event, the provision in this article and/or franchise agreement shall govern to the extent permitted by law. 
(Code 1976, § 15.56.060)  
Sec. 12-656. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  In addition to, and not in lieu, abrogation or diminishment of any and all remedies and penalties set forth elsewhere in this article upon any violation by a grantee and/or other person of any provision of this article, such grantee and/or person shall forfeit and pay to the City a sum of not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each violation, together with the costs of prosecution. 
(b)  Each day's continuance of a violation shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  In addition to, and not in lieu, abrogation or diminishment of imposition of the forfeitures set forth above, and in addition to, and not in lieu, abrogation or diminishment of any or all remedies and/or penalties set forth elsewhere in this article , upon a violation of any provision set forth in this article, the grantee and/or other person shall be subject to, and the City may seek the grant and imposition of, one and/or more equitable and/or legal order of the court, including, but not limited to, injunction and mandamus in order to effectuate and achieve compliance, performance, abatement, and/or such other legitimate public interest. 
(d)  Prior to the imposition of a penalty hereunder, the City shall provide a grantee with a 30-day notice and a right to cure the violation upon which such penalty is to be imposed. In the event of a failure to cure by a grantee within such 30 days, the penalty shall accrue from the first day of such violation. 
(Code 1976, § 15.56.070)  
Secs. 12-65712-690. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXI. - CABLE TELEVISION BASIC RATES 
 
Sec. 12-691. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  In addition to, and not in lieu, abrogation or diminishment of any and all remedies and penalties set forth elsewhere in this Code upon any violation by a grantee, other cable television provider or person of any provision of this article, such grantee, other provider or person shall: 
(1)  Forfeit and pay to the City such penalties as permitted and/or mandated by the applicable federal laws and applicable rules and regulations of the Federal Communication Commission, as from time to time amended; and/or 
(2)  Forfeit and pay to the City a penalty of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 per violation, together with the costs of prosecution, if permitted by law. 
(b)  Each day's continuance of a violation shall constitute a separate violation, if permitted by law. 
(c)  Upon default in payment of the forfeiture, the violator shall be incarcerated in the Rock County Jail for not more than 60 days and/or penalized otherwise in the manner as provided by law, if permitted by law. 
(Code 1976, § 15.58.020)  
Chapter 14 - FINANCE AND REVENUE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions concerning municipal budget systems, see Wis. Stats. Ch. 65. For provisions concerning municipal borrowing and municipal bonds, Wis. Stats. ch. 67. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions setting the calendar year as the fiscal year of a City, see Wis. Stats. 62.12. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Designated. 
The fiscal year shall be the calendar year. 
(Code 1976, § 3.04.010)  
Sec. 14-2. - Licenses; expiration date; not applicable when. 
(a)  Any and all licenses of every nature and kind hereafter issued by the City shall expire on June 30 following their issue. The full license year shall be from July 1 to July 1 for every kind of license. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to such licenses as those where dates of issue or expiration are fixed or determined by statute and over which the Council has no control, but shall apply to all licenses over which the Council has power to fix such dates. 
(Code 1976, § 3.04.020)  
Secs. 14-314-22. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET [3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions concerning municipal budgets, see Wis. Stats. § 65.90. 
 
Sec. 14-23. - Generally. 
It shall be the duty of the City Manager to submit and recommend to the Council, not later than November 15 of each year, an itemized estimate of budget covering the amount necessary to be raised by taxation for all City purposes for the ensuing fiscal year. The Council shall hold such hearings as may be required by Wis. Stats. § 65.90, if still in force and effect, or by any other statute, and shall thereupon consider such recommended budget and make such changes or additions as it determines to be necessary, and shall promptly adopt such budget as so amended. Changes in the amount or purpose of any appropriation shall be made in accordance with the procedure specified in Wis. Stats. § 65.90, if such section is still in force and effect, or by any other section which may then be applicable and effective. 
(Code 1976, § 3.08.010)  
Sec. 14-24. - Tax determination; appropriations. 
Upon the adoption of the yearly budget, the Council shall then officially determine the amount of money to be raised by taxation for all City purposes for the ensuing year, and shall likewise appropriate for the operation of each office, department or function the amount as fixed in each budget. 
(Code 1976, § 3.08.020)  
Secs. 14-2514-44. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DISBURSEMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions concerning disbursements from a local treasury, see Wis. Stats. § 66.042. For provisions concerning disbursements and the budget, see Wis. Stats. 62.12. For statutory provisions concerning claims, see Wis. Stats. §§ 62.12 and 62.25. 
 
Sec. 14-45. - Statutory conformance; definitions; signature authorization. 
Disbursements from the City Treasury shall be made as provided for by Wis. Stats. § 66.0821. When the term "Mayor" appears in such statute, it shall be construed to mean City Manager. During the absence or inability of the City Manager to sign or countersign checks or vouchers, the same may be signed by the president of the Council. 
(Code 1976, § 3.12.010)  
Sec. 14-46. - Expenditures; authorization; compliance; additional funds. 
The City Manager and City Treasurer shall have authority to expend City funds in strict compliance with the appropriations as made by the Council. No funds shall be expended and no obligations incurred, except by express action of the Council, in excess of such appropriations. In case the appropriation made for the use of any board, officer or department is insufficient, the Council may provide, by a majority vote of all members, additional funds for such need from any funds in the treasury which have not already been definitely appropriated for other purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 3.12.020)  
Sec. 14-47. - Signatures allowed. 
In lieu of the personal signatures of the City Manager and the City Clerk-Treasurer, these officers are authorized to affix their lithographed signatures to the City's order checks or other checks including required signatures on school board orders or checks as provided in Wis. Stats. 66.0821. 
(Code 1976, § 3.08.030)  
Secs. 14-4814-62. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SEWER AND WATER SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions concerning special assessments, see Wis. Stats. § 66.60 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-63. - Generally. 
In cases in which sewer and/or water mains have been laid abutting any property and no assessment has been levied against such property for the benefits from such main or mains, a special assessment shall be levied for the benefit against such property on connection with such sewer or water mains being made. 
(Code 1976, § 3.16.010)  
Sec. 14-64. - Cost per linear foot; adjustment when. 
Such assessment shall, subject to adjustment by the Council after a hearing if requested by the property owner, be based on the current cost per linear foot assessment for similar mains. 
(Code 1976, § 3.16.020)  
Sec. 14-65. - Hearing when; notice; amount determination. 
In case waivers of the assessment procedure are filed and/or the assessment paid, no hearing shall be necessary. In case the property owner requests permission to make a connection and does not file a waiver or pay the assessment or makes a connection without payment, the City Clerk shall give notice of the amount of the assessment and set a date for hearing by the Council. Notice of the hearing shall be given in writing to the property owner or his or her agent at least ten days prior to the hearing unless such notice is waived in writing. The Council shall determine the amount of the assessment at the hearing. 
(Code 1976, § 3.16.040)  
Sec. 14-66. - Appeal procedure. 
The property owner may appeal to the circuit court as provided in Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(12), provided notice of appeal is given within 40 days from the Council determination. If no such appeal is filed, the assessment shall be extended on the tax roll. 
(Code 1976, § 3.16.050)  
Secs. 14-6714-82. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ROOM TAX 
 
Sec. 14-83. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hotel or motel means a building or group of buildings in which the public may obtain accommodations for a consideration, including, without limitation, such establishments as inns, motels, tourist homes, tourist houses or courts, lodginghouses, roominghouses, summer camps, apartment hotels, resort lodges and cabins and any other building or group of buildings in which accommodations are available to the public. Exempt from the definition of the term "hotel" or "motel" are mobile homes, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.058(1)(d), and accommodations rented for a continuous period of more than one month and accommodations furnished by any hospitals, sanitoriums, or nursing homes, or by corporations or associations organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, provided that no part of the net earnings of such corporations and associations inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
Transient means any person residing for a continuous period of less than one month in a hotel, motel or other furnished accommodations available to the public. 
(Code 1976, § 3.20.010)  
Sec. 14-84. - Annual room tax. 
(a)  Pursuant to applicable provision of the currently Wis. Stats. § 66.75, a tax is imposed on the privilege and service of furnishing, at retail, of rooms or lodging to transients by hotel keepers, motel operators and other persons furnishing accommodations that are available to the public, pursuant to the above definitions, irrespective of whether membership is required for the use of the accommodations. 
(b)  Such annual room tax shall be at the rate of eight percent of the gross receipts from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodgings. 
(c)  Such tax shall not be subject to the selective sales tax imposed by Wis. Stats. § 77.52(2)(a)1. 
(Code 1976, § 3.20.020)  
Sec. 14-85. - Administration; returns. 
(a)  This article shall be administered by the City Clerk. 
(b)  Each person governed by this article shall have the following reporting period: 
Amount of Room Tax Due 	Reporting Period 
Less than $300.00 per year 	Annual 
At least $300.00 per year but not more than $600.00 in any one quarter 	Quarterly 
More than $600.00 in any one quarter 	Monthly 
 
(c)  A room tax return shall be filed with the City Clerk and the room tax imposed by this article shall be due and payable in full to the City no later than the last day of the month immediately following that person's reporting period, except that those persons whose room tax liability is greater than $3,600.00 per quarter shall file their room tax return no later than the 20th day of the month immediately following the end of their reporting period. 
(d)  The room tax return shall be in a form as required by the City Clerk and shall show, among other items, the gross receipts derived from the retail furnishing of rooms and lodging for that reporting period, the amount of taxes imposed for such period, and such other information as the City Clerk or his or her representative deems necessary, provided it is directly related to the tax. The City Clerk may, for good cause, extend the time of filing any return, but no longer than 30 days from the original filing due date. 
(e)  Each room tax return shall be signed by the person required to file such return or his or her duly authorized agent. The City Clerk may, for good cause, extend the time of filing any return, but not longer than 30 days from the filing date. 
(f)  For administration expenses in reporting the room tax and the accounting connected therewith, any person liable for any amount of tax imposed by this article may deduct two percent of the room tax due provided that the payment of the tax is not delinquent. 
(Code 1976, § 3.20.030)  
Sec. 14-86. - Successor's responsibility for tax payment. 
(a)  If any person, liable for any amount of tax imposed by this article, in any manner, in whole or in part, terminates, transfers, conveys, sells, gifts or divides his or her business stock of goods, his or her successor or assign shall withhold sufficient sums from the purchase price to fully and completely satisfy the tax imposed by this article.
