The subdivider shall submit a copy of the master site grading and drainage plan to the City as a digital file in a format specified by the City Engineer. 
(5)  Plats and certified survey maps for lands located outside the City of Janesville and within the City's extraterritorial plat review jurisdiction area are not subject to the requirements set forth in Subsection (4) of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.020; Ord. No. 77-5, § 1, 1977)  
Sec. 36-107. - Final platPortion of preliminary plat to be final plat; planner approval. 
If a subdivider wishes to make a final plat of a portion of an approved preliminary plat, he or she must first secure the City Planner's approval of the boundaries of such portion. 
(Prior Code, § 24.15(3)(c); Code 1976, § 17.16.030)  
Sec. 36-108. - Final platCopies and filing fee submitted to City Planner; review procedure. 
Thirteen copies of the final plat and master site grading and drainage plan, including the required filing fee, shall be submitted to the City Planner at least 12 days before the final plat is scheduled to be reviewed by the City Plan Commission. The applicant shall also submit a copy of the final plat in digital format satisfactory to the City Engineer. If the final plat is not submitted within 36 months of the last approval of the preliminary plat, the Plan Commission may refuse to approve the final plat. 
(Prior Code, § 24.05(3)(a); Code 1976, § 17.16.040; Ord. No. 74-424, § 2, 1974)  
Sec. 36-109. - Final platApproval and rejection procedure. 
The Plan Commission shall refer the final plat with its recommendation to the City Council within 30 days of its submission, unless the time is extended by the Council. The Council shall approve or reject the final plat within 60 days of its first submission to the City Clerk, unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. Reasons for rejection shall be stated in the minutes of the council meeting, and a copy thereof or a written statement of such reasons shall be supplied by the subdivider. The City recommends that the subdivider or his or her agent shall forward copies of the plat to the Wisconsin Department of Administration under the option set forth in Wis. Stats. § 236.12. 
(Prior Code, § 24.05(3)(b); Code 1976, § 17.16.050)  
Sec. 36-110. - Final platTrue copy filed in lieu of original when; approval requirements. 
If the original of the final plat has been filed with another approving authority, the subdivider may file a true copy of such plat in lieu of the original. However, before approval of the Council will be inscribed on the original of the final plat, the surveyor or the subdivider shall certify the respects in which the original of the final plat differs from the true copy, and all modifications must first be approved. 
(Prior Code, § 24.05(3)(c); Code 1976, § 17.16.060)  
Sec. 36-111. - Final platCity to receive digital copy. 
The surveyors, at no cost to the City, shall provide the City with an electronic copy of the final plat as processed by the Wisconsin Department of Administration. Upon recording, the surveyor shall submit a copy of the final plat in digital format satisfactory to the City Engineer. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.070)  
Sec. 36-112. - Certified surveyPurpose. 
All acts of dividing land within the City limits or within the extraterritorial plat jurisdiction must be regulated in the public interest, for in no other way can the City hope to ensure a comprehensive and coordinated program of good physical development. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(part); Code 1976, § 17.16.080)  
Sec. 36-113. - Certified surveyRequirements. 
Every division of land that results in a subdivision, as defined under this chapter, must be done by certified survey to be filed by the subdivider for record with the Rock County register of deeds after meeting all of the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.34 which is adopted by reference. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(1); Code 1976, § 17.16.090)  
Sec. 36-114. - Certified surveyPreliminary. 
Before submitting a final certified survey for approval, the subdivider shall submit a preliminary certified survey to the City Planner if the proposed land division is located within the City. If the proposed land division is outside the City limits, the preliminary certified survey is submitted to the Rock County Zoning Administrator. No final certified survey will be accepted for review which has not been preceded by an approved preliminary certified survey. The applicant shall also submit a copy of the preliminary certified survey to the City Planner in digital format satisfactory to the City Engineer. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.100)  
Sec. 36-115. - Certified surveyPreliminary grading and drainage plan. 
The preliminary grading plan shall be submitted as an electronic copy that is capable of legible reproduction, not to exceed 36 inches in width and a map scale of not more than 200 feet to the inch. The preliminary grading and drainage plan must include: 
(1)  Elevation of existing structures, existing ground contours and/or spot elevations. 
(2)  Off-site drainage basins that flow through the plat. 
(3)  Existing and proposed regional and local flood elevations. 
(4)  Arrows indicating the direction of proposed overland drainage flow. 
(5)  Drainage easements as necessary to accommodate the grading plan. 
(6)  Location and approximate configuration of proposed on-site drainage basins after grading subdivision if necessary as determined by the City Engineer. 
(7)  Appropriate stormwater calculations, if determined necessary by the City Engineer, to demonstrate that the facilities identified in Subsection (6) of this section are sufficient to meet all requirements of the City of Article IV of Chapter 32. 
(8)  Surveys for land located outside the City of Janesville and within the City's extraterritorial plat review jurisdiction area are not subject to the above requirements. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.105)  
Sec. 36-116. - Certified surveyFinal. 
Before recording a final certified survey of a land division located within three miles of the City limits, it shall be approved by the City Plan Commission and the City Council where dedication of land within the City is involved. Twelve copies of the final certified survey shall be submitted to the City Planner 12 days before the survey is scheduled to be reviewed by the City Plan Commission. Upon recording the final survey, the surveyor shall submit a copy of the final plat in digital format satisfactory to the City Engineer. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.110)  
Sec. 36-117. - Certified surveyStandards. 
(a)  This certified survey shall comply with Wis. Stats. § 236.34. 
(b)  The map shall indicate all existing buildings, structures, watercourses, and drainage facilities and other physical features. 
(c)  The certificate of approval of the secretary of the Plan Commission or Planning Director shall be placed on it, unless dedication of lands within the City is required, then the certificate of the City Clerk would be reproduced on the map. 
(d)  The map shall be filed for record with the register of deeds and two copies of such shall be given to the City Planning Division within 30 days of such recording. 
(e)  The map shall indicate all areas where sidewalks are to be constructed. The Council or Plan Commission may approve the certified survey subject to such changes as are deemed necessary. 
(f)  Master site grading and drainage plan. The final survey must include a final master site grading plan which shall contain information as outlined in the master site grading plan handbook on file in the City Engineering Division. The final master site grading plan must be submitted to the City as a digital file in a format specified by the City Engineer. 
(g)  Surveys located within the City's extraterritorial plat review jurisdiction area and outside of the City of Janesville and are not subject to the requirements of Subsection (f) of this section. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(3); Code 1976, § 17.16.120; Ord. No. 77-5, § 2, 1977)  
Sec. 36-118. - Certified surveyUtility easement dedications. 
Unless adequate provision has already been made in the area by dedication of land for utility easements, no certified survey can be approved until an adequate dedication is made for utility easements in the certified survey. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(4); Code 1976, § 17.16.130)  
Sec. 36-119. - Certified surveyApproval or rejection. 
The City Plan Commission shall, within 40 days of the filing of an application under Section 36-113, approve, approve conditionally, or reject the certified survey and notify the applicant of any conditions of approval or reasons for rejection. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(5); Code 1976, § 17.16.140)  
Sec. 36-120. - Certified surveySpecial assessment lands; regulations. 
No person, firm or corporation shall divide lands by certified survey or subdivision plat within the City on which special assessments have been levied without first, paying such special assessments in full, or without first, securing an agreement in writing by the parties to the division specifying the division of the assessment, and a separate description of the parcels to which the divided portions of the assessment shall apply. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(6); Code 1976, § 17.16.150)  
Sec. 36-121. - Certified surveyMap requirements waived when. 
In the case of lot splits, or the sale of land between adjoining owners, the Plan Commission may waive the requirements of the certified survey map if it will not be in conflict with the intent of this article. In addition, in the case of lot splits or the sale of land between adjoining owners, the City Planner may waive the requirements of the certified survey map if the land being transferred is less than 50 feet wide at the building setback line and if the lots resulting are not reduced below the minimum size of new lots required by this section, providing that evidence is given to the City Planner that the new lot line has been staked by a registered land surveyor. This evidence shall be in the form of either a plat of survey or a print of the area marked to show the new lot line stakes and stamped by the surveyor, and such evidence shall be submitted not later than 30 days following the recording of the instrument which transfers the land. 
(Prior Code, § 24.16(7); Code 1976, § 17.16.160; Ord. No. 76-491, § 1, 1976)  
Sec. 36-122. - No sales until final plat or certified survey is recorded. 
No subdivider or his or her agent shall offer or contract to convey, or convey any subdivision, as defined in this article, or lot or parcel which lies in a subdivision as defined in this title, or lot or parcel regulated by Sections 36-112 through 36-121, knowing that the final plat thereof or certified survey thereof has not been recorded; except that where the preliminary or final plat of the subdivision or certified survey has been filed for approval with the City, an offer or contract to convey may be made if that offer or contract states on its face that it is contingent upon approval of the final plat. Such offer or contract shall be void if such plat is not approved. 
(Prior Code, § 24.17; Code 1976, § 17.16.170)  
Sec. 36-123. - Fees. 
Subdividers shall pay all fees in amounts as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set out in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.180)  
Sec. 36-124. - Special assessment split fee. 
For administrative work to analyze and assign existing assessments to the new parcels, based upon the proposed land division, including, but not limited to, complication by many factors, including remainder parcels, resurveying of previously certified parcels, overlap, or other factors, the City of Janesville will charge a minimum fee, based on staff time required to fulfill such requests. The fee shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set out in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 17.16.190)  
Secs. 36-12536-146. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ALLEYS 
 
Sec. 36-147. - Business and industrial districts; requirements; exceptions. 
Alleys shall be provided in all business and industrial districts, except that the Plan Commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for fire protection and refuse disposal routes, and other service access such as off-street loading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(Prior Code, § 24.08(1); Code 1976, § 17.20.010)  
Sec. 36-148. - Residential areas. 
Alleys shall not be approved in residential areas, unless necessary because of topography or other exceptional circumstances. 
(Prior Code, § 24.08(2); Code 1976, § 17.20.020)  
Sec. 36-149. - Width requirement. 
The width of alleys shall be not less than 30 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 24.08(3); Code 1976, § 17.20.030)  
Secs. 36-15036-166. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - BLOCKS 
 
Sec. 36-167. - Regulations, generally. 
The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be such as are appropriate for the locality and the type of development contemplated, but block lengths in residential areas shall not exceed 1,500 feet nor be less than 600 feet between street lines, unless special approval is given for variations by the Plan Commission. 
(Prior Code, § 24.10(1); Code 1976, § 17.24.010)  
Sec. 36-168. - Pedestrian walkways required when. 
Pedestrian walkways not less than ten feet wide with a five-foot pavement may be required by the Plan Commission through the center of blocks more than 900 feet long where it is deemed essential. A note shall be placed upon the final plat stating that such pedestrian walkway shall be constructed and maintained entirely by the adjacent property owners. 
(Prior Code, § 24.10(2); Code 1976, § 17.24.020)  
Sec. 36-169. - Size determination. 
In general, the following things should be taken into consideration in determining the size of a block: 
(1)  The planned use of the land should be taken into consideration. Business and industrial uses require different sized blocks and lots than do residential areas. 
(2)  Need for convenient access, circulation control and safety of street traffic should be taken into consideration. Whenever practicable, blocks along arterial and collector streets should not be less than 1,000 feet long. 
(3)  Limitations and advantages of topography should be taken into consideration. 
(Prior Code, § 24.10(3); Code 1976, § 17.24.030)  
Secs. 36-17036-191. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - EASEMENTS 
 
Sec. 36-192. - Requirements, generally. 
Easements shall be provided and dedicated for installation of utilities and drainageways, and when in the public interest, scenic easements may be required. Generally, a ten-foot utility easement is required off of the rear lot line and eight feet off of the side lot line. Utility easements shall be noted along with the required dimensions upon the final plat or certified survey map. 
(Prior Code, § 24.09(1); Code 1976, § 17.28.010)  
Sec. 36-193. - Underground utilities. 
All facilities for distribution of electricity (excluding lines of 12,000 volts or more), telephone utility service in residential subdivisions, cable television service installed within a newly platted area, mobile home parks, cluster development or planned development districts shall be placed underground, unless the newly created lots or units are served by preexisting systems. 
(Prior Code, § 24.09(2); Code 1976, § 17.28.020)  
Sec. 36-194. - Watercourses. 
Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, floodplain, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or right-of-way conforming substantially with the line of such watercourse, drainageway, floodplain, channel or stream, and adequate for the purpose, in the judgment of the City Plan Commission. 
(Prior Code, § 24.12; Code 1976, § 17.28.030)  
Secs. 36-19536-211. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - LOTS 
 
Sec. 36-212. - Requirements, generally. 
The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision, and for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(1); Code 1976, § 17.32.010)  
Sec. 36-213. - Dimensions. 
(a)  Lots zoned residence shall have a minimum width of 70 feet at the building line, a minimum depth of 100 feet, and a minimum area of 7,700 square feet. Lots 65 feet in width may be allowed in locations where in the judgment of the Plan Commission such narrower lots are deemed advisable. However, no building permit shall be issued for any building which will be used primarily for residential purposes on any lot whose size was reduced below the above criteria after January 1, 1976. 
(b)  Residential lots to be served by private sewerage disposal facilities shall comply with the rules of the appropriate state and county agencies. 
(c)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for business and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by this Code. 
(d)  Residential lots, fronting on major streets and highways, should be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between the building and such traffic ways. 
(e)  Excessive depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A proportion of 2½ to one shall be considered as a desirable maximum for a width of 70 feet or more. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(2); Code 1976, § 17.32.020; Ord. No. 76-506, § 1, 1976; Ord. No. 76-6, § 1, 1977)  
Sec. 36-214. - Corner lots. 
Corner lots shall be made large enough so that setback lines thereon can fully conform with the setback lines regularly established for the plat, thus precluding the necessity of encroaching beyond the normal setbacks, notwithstanding any variations permitted by applicable zoning ordinances. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(3); Code 1976, § 17.32.030)  
Sec. 36-215. - Public street access. 
Every lot shall front or abut on a public street. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(4); Code 1976, § 17.32.040)  
Sec. 36-216. - Arrangement. 
Lots shall be so arranged that side lines abutting rear lines or other lots shall be avoided wherever possible, especially in residential areas. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(5); Code 1976, § 17.32.050)  
Sec. 36-217. - Side lot lines. 
Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(6); Code 1976, § 17.32.060)  
Sec. 36-218. - Size; resubdivision when. 
In case a tract is subdivided into parcels containing one or more acres, such parcels shall be arranged to allow the resubdivision of any parcels into normal lots in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(7); Code 1976, § 17.32.070)  
Sec. 36-219. - Municipal boundaries. 
Lots shall follow municipal boundary lines and shall not cross them. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(8); Code 1976, § 17.32.080)  
Sec. 36-220. - Double frontage. 
Double frontage on parallel streets shall be avoided, except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries, or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(9); Code 1976, § 17.32.090)  
Sec. 36-221. - Flag lots. 
Flag lots shall not be allowed unless, in the opinion of the Plan Commission, there is no other reasonable alternative. The stem of any flag lot shall be a minimum width of 30 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(10); Code 1976, § 17.32.100)  
Sec. 36-222. - Flood areas. 
No platting shall take place within the floodway district of the City, as delineated in the City floodplain overlay district. Within practical limits, all lands of a subdivision living within the floodway shall be dedicated to the public. 
(Prior Code, § 24.11(11); Code 1976, § 17.32.110)  
Sec. 36-223. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Before the City Treasurer signs any plat or certified survey, the subdivider shall list or show on the plat or certified survey the streets along which sidewalks are to be constructed, pursuant to Section 36-113 or 36-117(e). Such sidewalk placement is to be determined based on approved neighborhood plans for the area. 
(b)  Sidewalks listed or shown on plats or certified surveys may be constructed by the subdivider or by the owner of the property. If so constructed, sidewalks shall comply with the standards set forth in Sections 12-166 and 12-167. 
(c)  When 80 percent or more of the lots included in the certified survey have been developed or when 80 percent or more of the lots along any street in one block have been developed, the City Engineer shall place all the lots in the certified survey or all the lots along the one block of the street on the next occurring public works program for construction of any required sidewalk not yet constructed, but only if such proposed sidewalk would connect to an existing sidewalk unless pedestrian generators and destinations are both present in a localized area. The order for and cost of such construction shall be as provided for in Wis. Stats. § 66.615, as from time to time amended. If any such sidewalk is placed on a City Council agenda and is defeated, then the administration shall not place such sidewalk on a City Council agenda for the following two years. 
(Code 1976, § 17.32.120)  
Secs. 36-22436-254. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - PUBLIC SITES AND OPEN SPACES 
 
Sec. 36-255. - Generally. 
(a)  Every owner of land who desires to subdivide such land shall be required to provide land to the City for public sites and open spaces, or money in lieu of such land. If the master plan, master neighborhood plan, or official map indicates that public land, other than for streets or greenbelts, is proposed for the land within the subdivision, the owner shall dedicate such land to the City. The City shall not reimburse the owner for any land so dedicated, unless such dedication is for more than five percent of the total plat area. If such required dedication is less than five percent of the total plat area, the owner shall pay to the City a sum of money equal to five percent of the value of the total plat area less any land so dedicated. The City may accept, in lieu of such sum of money, land within the subdivision of equal value. 
(b)  Subdividers who desire approval of a certified survey may be required to dedicate as set out in Subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Any funds received by the City under this section shall be spent by the City solely for improvements in, acquisition of, changes or additions to public park lands, neighborhood parks or greenbelts in the area of the subdivision or in a community or regional City park wheresoever located. Any land accepted in lieu of such monies under this section may be sold by the City, and monies therefrom shall be spent by the City for improvements in, acquisition of, changes, or additions to any public park lands, neighborhood parks or greenbelts in the area of the subdivision or in a community or regional City park, wheresoever located. 
(Code 1976, § 17.36.010)  
Secs. 36-25636-273. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - STREETS 
 
Sec. 36-274. - Requirements, generally. 
The streets shall be designated and located in relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions and natural terrain features such as streams and existing tree growth, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(1); Code 1976, § 17.40.010)  
Sec. 36-275. - Conformance. 
The arrangement, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the master neighborhood plans, official sidewalk plans, official maps, and Janesville Area Long Range Transportation Plan of the City. 
(Code 1976, § 17.40.020)  
Sec. 36-276. - Janesville Area Long Range Transportation Plan; conformance. 
The right-of-way width of all proposed streets shall conform to the adopted Janesville Area Long Range Transportation Plan. 
(1)  Major streets shall be properly integrated with the existing and proposed system of major streets and highways. 
(2)  Collector streets shall be properly related to the mass transit system, to special traffic generating from facilities such as schools, churches and shopping centers, to population densities, and to major streets into which they feed. 
(3)  Minor streets shall be laid out to conform as much as possible to topography, to discourage use by through traffic, to permit efficient drainage and sewer systems, and to require the minimum amount of street necessary to provide convenient, safe access to property. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(3); Code 1976, § 17.40.030)  
Sec. 36-277. - Frontage roads. 
Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the Plan Commission may require a 50-foot-wide street parallel to and on either or both sides of such right-of-way, for purposes of conveying traffic between individual driveways and designated access points to the highway. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(4); Code 1976, § 17.40.040)  
Sec. 36-278. - Major streets. 
Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major street, the Plan Commission may require that frontage roads be provided. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(5); Code 1976, § 17.40.050)  
Sec. 36-279. - Right-of-way width requirements. 
The right-of-way and road way of all streets shall be of the width specified in the Janesville Area Long Range Transportation Plan, on the official map or master plan, or if no width is specified in the Janesville Area Long Range Transportation Plan, on the official map or master plan, they shall be not less than the width specified below: 
(1)  Primary and standard arterials, 100 feet; 
(2)  Collector streets, 80 feet; 
(3)  Minor and local streets, 70 feet except that right-of-way widths of 60 feet may be permitted when recommended by the City Engineer and approved by the Plan Commission; 
(4)  Alleys, 30 feet; 
(5)  Frontage roads, 30 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(6); Code 1976, § 17.40.060)  
Sec. 36-280. - Street width applications. 
(a)  Streets having widths of 28 feet measured from face of curb to face of curb may be approved as determined appropriate by the City Engineer. Parking should be restricted on one side of the street and designated at the time of preliminary plat approval. 
(b)  Street widths less than 28 feet measured from face of curb to face of curb may be permitted when recommended by City Engineering and approved by the Plan Commission if on-street parking is restricted, access is limited and physical or topographic constraints make such a lesser width appropriate. 
(Code 1976, § 17.40.065)  
Sec. 36-281. - Grades established. 
Grades shall be established by the City Engineer. The grade of major and collector streets shall not exceed six percent, and the grade of all other streets shall not exceed 12 percent. The minimum grade of all streets shall be four-tenths percent. The standards in this section may be varied when necessitated by exceptional topography when the variation is approved by the City Plan Commission. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(7); Code 1976, § 17.40.070)  
Sec. 36-282. - Horizontal curves. 
The minimum radii or curvature on the centerline shall be not less than the following, unless necessitated by unusual or special conditions subject to the approval of the City Engineer: 
(1)  Arterial streets, 350 feet; 
(2)  Collector streets, 200 feet; 
(3)  Minor streets, 150 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(8); Code 1976, § 17.40.080)  
Sec. 36-283. - Vertical curves. 
All changes in street grades shall be connected by vertical curves. The length and elevations of such vertical curves shall be determined by the City Engineer. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(9); Code 1976, § 17.40.090)  
Sec. 36-284. - Tangents. 
A tangent at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major streets, and 25 feet on minor streets, and at all block corners. Where there is a deflection angle of more than ten degrees in the alignment of a street, a curve shall be introduced with the required radius. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(10); Code 1976, § 17.40.100)  
Sec. 36-285. - Names. 
(a)  All dedication for street purposes shall bear a street name approved by the City Plan Commission and City Council. 
(b)  Street names within the jurisdictional limits of the City shall not duplicate or sound similar to existing street names. 
(c)  No new street name may be used to honor any living person. 
(d)  Existing street names shall be projected wherever possible. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(11); Code 1976, § 17.40.110; Ord. No. 75-472, § 8, 1975)  
Sec. 36-286. - Cul-de-sacs. 
(a)  The use of cul-de-sacs will not be allowed unless the Plan Commission grants special permission and finds that due to unusual shape, size, location or topography, the development may be better served by cul-de-sacs than by continuous streets. 
(b)  Cul-de-sacs shall be no longer than 600 feet. The radius of the right-of-way of the end of a cul-de-sac shall be at least 60 feet. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(12); Code 1976, § 17.40.120)  
Sec. 36-287. - Reserve strips. 
Reserve strips controlling access to streets and public property shall be prohibited, except where their control is definitely placed in the City under conditions approved by the Plan Commission. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(13); Code 1976, § 17.40.130)  
Sec. 36-288. - Half streets. 
Half streets shall not be permitted. Where a half street is proposed by the subdivider, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider or adjacent owner. 
(Prior Code, § 24.06(14); Code 1976, § 17.40.140)  
Sec. 36-289. - IntersectionsRight angles required. 
Streets shall intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, the block angle shall not be less than 75 degrees, and not more than two streets shall intersect at any one point. 
(Prior Code, § 24.07(1); Code 1976, § 17.40.150)  
Sec. 36-290. - IntersectionsSpecial conditions. 
Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded only on special conditions, and where the Plan Commission considers it necessary. Such special conditions shall be when streets intersect at an acute angle of 85 degrees or less, and the radii of such special curves shall be of such length as required by the City Engineer. Street curb intersections shall be rounded by radii of 20 feet or more, as required by the City Engineer. 
(Prior Code, § 24.07(2); Code 1976, § 17.40.160)  
Sec. 36-291. - Street jogs not permitted when. 
Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. Where streets intersect major streets, their alignment shall be continuous. 
(Prior Code, § 24.07(3); Code 1976, § 17.40.170)  
Secs. 36-29236-315. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - STORM SEWERS 
 
Sec. 36-316. - Construction fees. 
(a)  It is found and declared that division and subdivision of land in the City has necessitated and will necessitate the construction of storm sewers to transport stormwater and other surface runoff; requires construction of increasingly larger trunks as runoff is collected from various areas and brought together to be disposed of; that such a plan requires construction in areas removed from the immediate land being divided and served by the storm sewer; that the benefit to each division of land is substantially equal no matter where on the storm sewer system that land happens to exist; that this required construction is specifically and uniquely attributable to the activities of subdividers; that the ordinance codified in this section is enacted in order to facilitate adequate provision for the transportation of this water; that storm sewers are necessary to the public health, safety and welfare; that the cost for storm sewers is one that should be borne by those that create the need for the storm sewers; and that the necessity in the public interest for the provisions enacted in this section is declared as a matter of legislative determination. 
(b)  (1)  At the time any plat, certified survey or other subdivision is presented for approval, or at the time a building permit is requested for any parcel that has not paid storm sewer assessment, other than for those areas specifically defined or designated elsewhere in this article, the developer shall deposit with the City Clerk-Treasurer a sum of money to be used to pay for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements. Except as set forth elsewhere in this article, the City shall charge and developers shall pay to the City for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements per acre. The charge shall be in an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set out in the fee schedule that appears in this Code. No such money shall be spent for any purpose except to pay for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements. The total cost shall be computed by multiplying the cost per acre by the total number of acres included in the plat, certified survey or other subdivision. The assessment rate will be evaluated annually and a new rate established each year to assure recovery of not less than 100 percent of the cost of storm sewer design and construction. The City Council shall be advised of the new rate and the City Council hereby authorizes the adjustment and assessment of such rates. 
(2)  a.  The northeast drainage basin is a specifically defined area northeast of and including part of the City of Janesville that due to unique topographic, drainage and related characteristics and factors requires a large 60-acre drainage pond and related extensive and expensive stormwater drainage and sewer work specific to that area and not typical for other areas in and immediately surrounding the City at this time. The northeast drainage basin is defined in Subsection (b)(2)b of this section. At the time any plat, certified survey or other subdivision is presented for approval, or at the time a building permit is requested for any parcel in the northeast drainage basin, the developer shall deposit with the City Clerk a sum of money to be used to pay for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements in the northeast drainage basin. For this specifically defined area, the City shall charge and developers shall pay to the City an amount as established by the City Council from time to time, and as set out in the fee schedule that appears in this Code per acre to be used to pay for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements therein. No such money shall be spent for any purpose except to pay for the design and construction of storm sewers and storm drainage improvements. The total cost shall be computed by multiplying the cost per acre by the total number of acres included in the plat, certified survey or other subdivision. The assessment rate will be evaluated annually and a new rate established each year to ensure recovery of not less than 100 percent of the cost of storm sewer design and construction. The City Council shall be advised of the new rate and the City Council hereby authorizes the adjustment and assessment of such rates. 
b.  The term "northeast drainage basin" means and includes the following areas set forth in the attached map labeled Exhibit A, which map is incorporated herein as if fully set forth verbatim. 
c.  Such deposit shall be made before the involved plat, certified survey or other subdivision will be approved by the City. 
d.  Waiver procedure for storm sewer and stormwater facility charges. 
1.  The City Council may, following recommendation by the Plan Commission, accept and approve a waiver of assessment procedure for the cost of storm sewer and stormwater facilities for a particular subdivision plat or certified survey in lieu of a cash payment at the time of land division approval (Ref. Ordinance No. 71-237). This requires that each individual situation be examined upon its own merits as to whether or not such privilege is in the City's best interest. 
2.  The waiver of special assessment procedure must be requested by the owner, subdivider, or developer in writing at least 14 days prior to the scheduled Council meeting at which the final plat, certified survey, or land division is to be approved. 
3.  Upon request for the waiver procedure, the staff shall calculate the total cost of the storm sewer and stormwater charges according to the prevailing rate per acre. This total charge shall be divided equally to each parcel or lot in the subdivision or certified survey or shall be divided according to parcel area if appropriate because of oversized lots or large sites. The waiver document shall be prepared listing both the total cost and the individual lot or parcel cost. 
4.  The owner of each parcel so affected by the storm sewer and stormwater charges shall sign the waiver document which shall be properly notarized as called for in the document. One hundred percent of the individual owners, and developer must sign the waiver document agreeing to the special assessments to be levied. 
5.  The City Council, prior to approving the subdivision plat, certified survey, or land division should review the storm sewer and stormwater charges and determine whether or not they will require the cash deposit or allow the waiver procedure as requested. If the Council, following recommendation of the Plan Commission, allows the waiver procedure, the subdivision plat, certified survey, or land division can be approved. Immediately following such approval, the Council shall approve the waiver of assessment procedure, thereby levying the special assessments for storm sewer as listed thereon. 
6.  Those lands which fall outside or beyond the provisions of said Ordinance No. 71-237 establishing storm sewer charges, are subject to the charges at the same rate per acre to be levied in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.60. 
7.  Exception. An exception to this policy may be made relative to the proposed charges, rates, and waiver procedure when in the judgement of the Council there will be a substantial economic gain to the City. 
(c)  No charge shall be made for any plat, certified survey or other subdivision which receives no benefit whatsoever from storm sewers paid for by such deposits. 
(d)  The Plan Commission shall be the agency which shall review any initial determination made pursuant to this section. 
(d)  This article shall take effect upon adoption, the public health, welfare and good order so requiring. 
 
(Code 1976, § 17.44.010)  
Secs. 36-31736-335. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 36-336. - Construction; new installation. 
(a)  It is found and declared that division and subdivision of land in the City has necessitated and will continue to necessitate and construction, installation, maintenance and use of sidewalks to provide the safe, effective and appropriate movement of pedestrians, including, but not limited to, the elderly, children, persons with special physical attributes as well as residents and property owners of all kinds and nature; that the safe movement of vehicular traffic requires the installation and maintenance of sidewalks; that new areas of development provide the most efficient, effective and low cost means for installation; that the City has adopted a comprehensive plan and one or more other policies providing for sidewalk installation; that such plans require construction of sidewalks in new development areas, occasionally in areas removed from improved properties; that the ordinance codified in this section is enacted in order to facilitate the legitimate and pressing health, welfare and safety of pedestrian and vehicular needs and responsibilities of the City; that sidewalks are necessary and beneficial to the health, welfare and safety of the City, its residents and general public; and the necessity in the public interest for the provisions enacted in this article is declared a matter of legislative determination. 
(b)  The Plan Commission shall be the agency which shall review any initial determination made pursuant to this article. 
(c)  The City Engineer shall, consistent with Wisconsin Statutes and without the necessity for additional action by the City Council, order and/or cause the installation/construction of sidewalks within 12 months of issuance of occupancy permit or in the event that 80 percent or more of an existing or future subdivision, tract, plat, survey or area becomes developed, whichever occurs first. Nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting any individual property owner from requesting or effectuating installation of a sidewalk in front of such owner's property. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this article, each and every property owner shall comply with each and every other code provision pertaining to sidewalks, including, but not limited to, maintenance and sidewalk installation. 
(e)  Any plat, certified survey, or other division of land presented to the City for approval, and as a condition of approval, shall be required to contain and construct sidewalks on both sides of each street including cul-de-sacs set forth in and applied to all areas of the proposed plat, certified survey, or other land division. Sidewalk installation on both sides of the street in all new subdivisions is subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Where an existing street ends at mid-block with no existing or designated sidewalks, and a certified survey map or plat is proposed to extend that street, no sidewalk shall be required for said new street portion to block corner unless authorized by the City Council. 
(2)  The City Council may modify this section where the sidewalk placement is not physically practical. 
(Code 1976, § 17.46.010)  
Secs. 36-33736-360. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - STREET LIGHTING 
 
Sec. 36-361. - Construction; new installation; cost satisfaction by subdivider. 
(a)  It is found and declared that division and subdivision of land in the City has necessitated and will continue to necessitate the construction, installation, maintenance and use of street lights to facilitate traffic flow, pedestrian safety, and property security; that this required installation of new street lights is specifically, uniquely, fairly and appropriately attributable in necessity and cost to the activities of subdividers; that the ordinance codified in this section is enacted in order to facilitate the legitimate and pressing health, welfare and safety of citizens and responsibilities of the City; that street lights are necessary and beneficial to the health, welfare and safety of the City, its residents and the general public; that the cost of initial street lighting is one that should be borne by those who create the need for the subdivision and/or land use; and the necessity in the public interest for the provisions enacted in this article is declared a matter of legislative determination. 
(b)  The Plan Commission shall be the agency which shall review any initial determination made pursuant to this article. 
(c)  New streetlight installations under this article shall be constructed as is customary for public works projects of this kind in accordance with applicable law. 
(Code 1976, § 17.47.010)  
Secs. 36-36236-380. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - MONUMENTS 
 
Sec. 36-381. - Requirement, generally. 
The subdivision shall be monumented as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.15, which is adopted by reference. 
(Prior Code, § 24.14; Code 1976, § 17.48.010)  
Secs. 36-38236-405. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - VARIANCES 
 
Sec. 36-406. - Generally. 
When, in the judgment of the Plan Commission or the City Council, it would be inappropriate to apply literally a provision of this article because the subdivision is located outside the corporate limits, or because extraordinary hardships would result, it may waive or vary such provisions so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that in no event shall the requirement of filing and recording the plat or survey maps be waived. 
(Prior Code, § 24.18; Code 1976, § 17.52.010)  
Sec. 36-407. - Planned developments. 
Proposed developments that require major variances from these standards shall be submitted as planned developments. 
(Prior Code, § 24.19; Code 1976, § 17.52.020)  
Secs. 36-40836-427. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - VIOLATIONS 
 
Sec. 36-428. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $25.00 nor more than $200.00, and the costs of prosecution, for each violation, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until payment thereof, but not exceeding 30 days. Each day a violation exists or continues constitutes a separate offense. In addition, the remedies provided by Wis. Stats. §§ 236.30 and 236.31(2), shall be available to the City. 
(Prior Code, § 24.21; Code 1976, § 17.56.010)  
Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Vehicles and traffic, generally, Wis. Stats. chs. 340350; powers of local authorities, Wis. Stats. ch. 349; authority of local authorities to adopt traffic regulations in conformity with state law, Wis. Stats. § 349.06 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - State traffic laws adopted. 
Except as prohibited by law, all provisions of Wis. Stats. chs. 340348, inclusive, describing and defining regulations and procedures with respect to vehicles and traffic are adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute so incorporated by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated by this chapter are also adopted and incorporated in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic in Wisconsin. 
(Code 1976, § 10.04.010; Ord. No. 82-298, § 1(part), 1982)  
Sec. 38-2. - Wisconsin Administrative Code adopted. 
Except as prohibited by law, all provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code describing and defining regulations and procedures with respect to vehicles and traffic are adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by the Wisconsin Administrative Code so incorporated by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the provisions incorporated by this chapter are also adopted and incorporated in order to secure uniform statewide regulation of traffic in Wisconsin. 
(Code 1976, § 10.04.015; Ord. No. 82-298, § 1(part), 1982)  
Sec. 38-3. - Violation; penalty. 
The penalty for violating Sections 38-1 and 38-2 shall be a forfeiture as provided in the applicable penalty provisions of Chapters 340348 of the Wisconsin Statutes (Wis. Stats. chs. 340348), together with the costs and disbursements of the action. In default of payment, the violator shall be imprisoned according to the applicable provisions of Wis. Stats. chs. 340348, but for not less than five days. 
(Code 1976, § 10.04.020; Ord. No. 82-298, § 1(part), 1982)  
Secs. 38-438-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 38-25. - Generally. 
In this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meaning designated in this chapter unless a different meaning is expressly provided or the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.010; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-26. - Bus loading zone. 
Bus loading zone means the area adjacent to the curbline of any street in which no person shall park, stop, or leave standing any vehicle except a motor bus, as defined by Wisconsin Statutes. Such bus loading zone shall be indicated by official traffic signs or markers stating "bus loading zone" or "bus stop." 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.020; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-27. - Leased parking. 
Leased parking means a parking stall or area that is leased from the City to a specific individual or business and which entitles such individual or business to exclusive use of such stall or area at all times during the term of the lease. 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.030; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-28. - Loading zone. 
Loading zone means the area adjacent to the curbline of any street in which no person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle for any purpose or length of time unless actually engaged in unloading and delivery or receipt and loading of merchandise, material or passengers. 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.040; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-29. - Official traffic signs or markers. 
Official traffic signs or markers means all signs, signals, markings and devices placed or erected by authority of the public body having jurisdiction for the purpose of regulating traffic or parking. A curb painted yellow, whether solidly or intermittently, shall be considered an official marker indicating that the parking of vehicles is prohibited in the street immediately adjacent to such painted curb. 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.050; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-30. - Parallel parking. 
Parallel parking means a method of parking in which a vehicle shall be parked facing in the direction of traffic with the wheels that are nearest the curb or edge of the street within 12 inches of such curb or edge of the street. The vehicle shall be parked at least two feet from the nearest vehicle unless a different parking space or system of parallel parking is clearly indicated. 
(Code 1976, § 10.08.060; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Secs. 38-3138-48. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CITY MANAGER AUTHORITY 
 
Sec. 38-49. - Purpose. 
To promote the public safety and general welfare, and to provide more flexibility in the use of public streets and public parking lots, and to increase speed of adaption to changing conditions, and to decrease the cost of publishing ordinances, this delegation of authority, as set out in this article, has been established for the purpose of utilizing the authority which may be delegated by the City Council pursuant to Chapter 349 of the Wisconsin Statutes (Wis. Stats. ch. 349). 
(Code 1976, § 10.12.010; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-50. - Delegation of duties to City Manager. 
The City Council delegates to the City Manager, or his or her designee, such authority as may be delegated by Chapter 349 of the Wisconsin Statutes (Wis. Stats. ch. 349) to control the public streets and parking lots of the City, and to establish, alter or repeal rules and regulations concerning such areas. No such rule or regulation shall be made in contravention of any ordinance, and in case of conflict between any such rule or regulation and an ordinance, the ordinance shall control. No rule or regulation shall be adopted pursuant to this section until the City Manager, or his or her designee, has first consulted with the Director of Public Works, the Chief of Police, and the City Engineer. No rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this section shall be effective unless official traffic signs or markers have been placed or erected indicating the particular prohibition, limitation or restriction. A list of all current rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this section shall be kept on file in the City Engineer's office and shall be open to public inspection during regular office hours. 
(Code 1976, § 10.12.020)  
Sec. 38-51. - Designation of areas. 
Pursuant to the authority delegated to the City Manager in this article, the City Manager shall designate and cause to be appropriately signed the areas on the streets and in public parking lots with specific time limitations, the areas reserved for leased parking, and the areas in which specific rules or regulations apply, including, but not limited to, bus loading zones, handicapped parking areas, loading zones and no parking areas. 
(Code 1976, § 10.12.030; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-52. - Leased parking fees. 
The City Manager shall provide for leasing stalls in leased parking areas. The fee for a leased stall may vary depending upon the location of such stall. The fee for a leased stall shall be established by the City Manager as part of the rules and regulations. 
(Code 1976, § 10.12.040; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Sec. 38-53. - Temporary parking regulation. 
The City Manager or the Chief of Police is authorized to make temporary parking regulations to provide for unusual conditions or to test the feasibility of such regulations. No such temporary parking regulations shall be valid unless such regulations have been reviewed by the City Engineer and the area affected is posted with official traffic signs or markers. No such temporary parking regulations shall remain in effect for more than 90 days. A list of such regulations shall be placed on file in the City Engineer's office and shall be open to public inspection during regular office hours. 
(Code 1976, § 10.12.050; Ord. No. 83-335, § 1(part), 1983)  
Secs. 38-5438-79. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - ONE-WAY STREETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference For statutory provisions authorizing local authorities to designate highways under their jurisdiction as one-way, Wis. Stats. § 349.10. 
 
Sec. 38-130. - Designation. 
The following streets are designated as one-way streets, and traffic shall proceed thereon as indicated in this section: 
(1)  Traffic on Wisconsin Street between Court and East Milwaukee Streets shall be in a northerly direction toward East Milwaukee Street. 
(2)  a.  West Milwaukee Streets from its intersection with Centerway and West Court Street easterly to a point 80 feet west of the west line of Locust Street; and 
b.  East Milwaukee Street from its intersection with Atwood Avenue to its intersection with Garfield Avenue are designated as one-way streets on which traffic shall move in a southwesterly direction only at all times. 
(3)  West Court Street from its intersection with Center Avenue and West Milwaukee Street easterly to the west side of Academy intersection and East Court Street from east of the intersection with Adams Street easterly to the intersection of Ringold Street are designated as one-way streets on which traffic shall move in an easterly direction only at all times. 
(4)  Traffic on Jefferson School Drive is to move from North Harmony Drive westerly, and then southerly to Mt. Zion Avenue. 
(5)  On North Jackson Street, traffic shall be in a southeasterly direction only, between Mineral Point Avenue and Madison Street. 
(6)  On North Washington Street, traffic shall be in a southeasterly direction only, between Highland Avenue and North Terrace Street. 
(7)  On North Terrace Street, traffic shall be in a southerly direction only, between North Washington Street and Mineral Point Avenue. 
(8)  On Parker Place, traffic shall be in a southerly direction only, between East Wall Street and East Milwaukee Street. 
(9)  On Cherry Street, traffic shall be in a southerly direction only, between Court Street and McKinley Street. 
(Code 1976, § 10.20.010; Ord. No. 2018-711, 2-26-2018 )  
Sec. 38-131. - Violation; penalty. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $20.00 nor more than $200.00, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment thereof, shall be imprisoned in the Rock County Jail for a period of not more than 60 days. 
(Code 1976, § 10.20.020; Ord. No. 83-335, § 4(part), 1983)  
Secs. 38-13238-160. - Reserved. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.11(5), 349.10(1)(b) and (d), 349.10 (1). The department, county highway committees and local authorities in regard to highways under their respective jurisdictions.

ARTICLE VIII. - PROHIBITED TURNS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference See Wis. Stats. §§ 349.10(1)(c) and 349.10(1). The department, county highway committees and local authorities in regard to highways under their respective jurisdictions, may: (c) By order, ordinance or resolution and by the erection of appropriate signs, prohibit right or left turns at intersections by all vehicles or by certain types of vehicles. 
 
Sec. 38-196. - Certain U-turns; left and right turns; prohibited. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle may not back the vehicle at an intersection controlled by an official traffic control device for the purpose of making a U-turn and shall not turn the vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon a highway at any of the following places: 
(1)  At any intersection at which traffic is being controlled by a traffic officer unless instructed by the officer to make a U-turn; 
(2)  In mid-block on any street in a business district; 
(3)  In mid-block on any through highway in a residence district; 
(4)  On any one-way street; 
(5)  At any place where signs prohibiting a U-turn have been erected by the city; 
(6)  At any place where a U-turn cannot be made safely or without interfering with other traffic; 
(7)  At any one of the following median openings: 
a.  In the 3000 block of Milton Avenue located approximately 665 feet south of the centerline of U.S. Highway 14. 
b.  In the 3300 block of Milton Avenue located approximately 575 feet north of the centerline of U.S. Highway 14. 
c.  In the 2000 block of U.S. Highway 14 located approximately 545 feet west of Milton Avenue. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle westbound on West Milwaukee Street shall not make a left turn at the intersection of Milwaukee Street, Court Street, Center Avenue and Centerway so as to go eastbound on West Court Street. 
(c)  The operator of a vehicle southbound on the easterly leg of South Jackson Street shall not make a right turn at the intersection of Kellogg Avenue so as to go westbound on Kellogg Avenue. 
(d)  The operator of a vehicle southbound on the westerly leg of South Jackson Street shall not make a left turn at the intersection of Kellogg Avenue so as to go eastbound on Kellogg Avenue. 
(Code 1976, § 10.28.010)  
Sec. 38-197. - Certain left and right turns; times; prohibited 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle shall not make a left turn between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. when such turn is prohibited by official sign: 
(1)  From Milwaukee Street onto Parker Drive. 
(2)  From Milwaukee Street onto Main Street. 
(3)  From Milwaukee Street onto River Street. 
(4)  From Milwaukee Street onto Jackson Street. 
(5)  From Milwaukee Street onto High Street. 
(6)  From Milwaukee Street onto Academy Street. 
(7)  From Milwaukee Street onto Locust Street. 
(8)  From Court Street onto Franklin Street. 
(9)  From Court Street onto River Street. 
(10)  From Court Street onto Parker Drive. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle shall not make a right turn between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. when such turn is prohibited by official sign: 
(1)  From Milwaukee Street onto Parker Drive. 
(2)  From Milwaukee Street onto Main Street. 
(3)  From Milwaukee Street onto River Street. 
(4)  From Milwaukee Street onto Franklin Street. 
(5)  From Court Street onto Academy Street. 
(6)  From Court Street onto Cherry Street. 
(7)  From Court Street onto High Street. 
(8)  From Court Street onto Jackson Street. 
(9)  From Court Street onto River Street. 
(Code 1976, § 10.28.020)  
Sec. 38-198. - Violation; penalty. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, pay a forfeiture of not less than $20.00 nor more than $200.00, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of the forfeiture payment, shall be imprisoned in the Rock County Jail for a period of not more than 60 days, or the court may suspend such defaulting violator's Wisconsin motor vehicle operator's privilege in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1976, § 10.28.030)  
Secs. 38-19938-219. - Reserved.
